properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values near minus 55 will moderate tonight as temperatures slowly rise. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-16T11:29:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-15T20:22:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2204802041.2020
Area: Gjoa Haven
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall, blowing snow and strong winds are occurring. Additional snowfall amounts: 10 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 to 110 km/h. Locations: the west coast of Newfoundland. Time span: continuing until Wednesday afternoon or evening. Remarks: Strongest wind gusts will occur over the Port au Port Peninsula and areas south to Channel-Port aux Basques. Winds will begin to ease on Wednesday morning. Conditions will begin to improve for some areas on Wednesday afternoon as snow changes to flurries, which will eventually taper off overnight on Wednesday night. Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-16T17:36:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-16T01:37:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0736762913.2020
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels are expected. Locations: east and northeast coasts, between St. John's and La Scie. Time span: Wednesday to Thursday. Remarks: Higher than normal water levels are likely during the high tide of Wednesday morning, and possible again Thursday morning due to a combination of storm surge and large waves. Minor coastal flooding or erosion may occur. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific frontal system had brought near 10 cm of snow to Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass today. Further snow accumulations of 10 cm are expected tonight. Meanwhile, another Pacific front will approach the Kootenays tomorrow. Snow from the system will start tomorrow afternoon and will intensify tomorrow night with up to 20 cm of snow expected by Thursday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-16T14:59:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-15T23:00:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3849107437.2020
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow tonight for Highway 97 and the Pine Pass. A storm system will stall over the region tonight. Snow will become heavy at times tonight with a total of 10 cm by Wednesday morning. Flurries will likely continue on Wednesday. Heavy snow will return for Wednesday night with the potential of blowing snow and reduced visibility Wednesday overnight into Thursday morning. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected to develop this evening as wind speeds increase. Winds will weaken after midnight allowing visibility in blowing snow to improve. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. High levels of pollutants are expected to persist until Wednesday morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-12-16T18:19:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2020-12-16T01:23:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4279570765.2020
Area: La Sarre area, Amos area, Lebel-sur-Quévillon area, Senneterre area, Rouyn area, Malartic area, Val d'Or - Louvicourt area
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Flurries, snowsqualls, and blowing snow are expected to continue. Total snowfall: in excess of 30 centimetres by Wednesday evening. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 90 km/h. Locations: western Cape Breton. Time span: tonight and Wednesday. Remarks: snowfall rates will begin to diminish through the day on Wednesday as the winds begin to ease. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-16T17:51:45-00:00

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for Wednesday. A narrow band of lake effect snow is expected to develop off Lake Ontario overnight and move inland early Wednesday morning. This band will be over the Burlington area early Wednesday morning and slowly shift northwards reaching the southwestern section of the City of Toronto by mid morning. Through the afternoon the band will drift south, reaching downtown Hamilton in the evening. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible by Wednesday overnight with snowfall rates of several centimeters per hour likely. Under the lake effect bands heavy bursts of snow and blowing snow can significantly reduce visibilities. Motorists are advised to exercise caution and be prepared for quickly changing driving conditions. Consider postponing non essential travel as snow covered and icy roads are expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-16T16:12:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-16T00:13:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3626724427.2020
Area: City of Toronto, City of Hamilton, Mississauga - Brampton, Halton Hills - Milton, Burlington - Oakville

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall may occur on Thursday. Locations: most of mainland Nova Scotia Time span: Beginning Thursday morning and ending early Friday morning. Remarks: There is considerable uncertainty as to the amount of snowfall these regions will receive. However, current indications are that there is the potential for accumulations greater than 15 cm to occur in some areas of mainland Nova Scotia Thursday. As with most storms that pass south of Nova Scotia, a small difference in the forecast track will could result in a significant change in the snowfall forecast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect through Wednesday afternoon. Lake effect snow off of Lake Superior is occurring. properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A robust frontal system will be approaching Vancouver Island Wednesday morning. Ahead of the frontal system strong southeasterly winds will develop over Victoria. At the peak the southeasterly winds will be 70 km/h near the water mid Wednesday afternoon. By later Wednesday evening, the winds will ease from the southeast and become strong out of the west. Winds will ease below criteria Thursday morning but it will remain breezy through Thursday. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of significant snowfall is occurring. Additional snowfall expected: 10 to 15 cm. Time span: continuing until Wednesday night. Locations: Happy Valley-Goose Bay and areas eastward along the Trans-Labrador Highway to Cartwright Junction. Remarks: Strong northwesterly winds tonight and Wednesday will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow over exposed areas. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-16T17:43:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-16T01:44:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1595824935.2020
Area: Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. 10 to 15 cm of snow will fall on Wednesday as a stationary front develops over the regions from Beaver Creek to Carmacks. Snow will ease to a few flurries Wednesday night as the front dissipates. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-16T14:55:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-15T22:56:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0545406180.2020
Area: Beaver Creek, Pelly - Carmacks
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is occurring. Snowfall tonight: 5 to 10 cm. Snowfall Wednesday: 15 to 25 cm. Snowfall Wednesday night: near 10 cm. Locations: Postville and Makkovik. Remarks: Snow will become heavy, at times, on Wednesday. Temperatures along the coast will remain near the freezing mark throughout this event, which could result in reduced accumulations. Higher snowfall amounts are possible inland and over higher terrain. Strong winds may cause reduced visibility in blowing snow over exposed areas on Wednesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-16T17:44:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-16T01:45:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3497751220.2020
Area: Postville - Makkovik
properties.Author: Environment Canada
